last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2362039
>>2362367
There'll be motorways and dual carriageways to most of Wales. You'll almost certainly have to spend some time driving on winding A-roads and if you're visiting rural parts, you may get taken down narrow single lane roads.

Two things to remember: lots of country roads are national limit but that's mostly because they can't be bothered to keep changing the limits. If you drive down a single lane narrow road at 70mph you'll obviously have a bad time (drive to your visibility on the road, if you are freaking out and driving very slowly that's also fine but pull over occasionally to let people pass).

The other is that there are average speed cameras on some major roads in Wales. Obey those and watch out for cunt HGV drivers who set their GPS calibrated Cruise control to "speed limit +1mph" and tailgate anyone in front of them sticking to the limit, trying to accelerate away from those is a good way to get a ticket, just pull in and let them be cunts to someone else.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: I work on a cruise ship AMA
threads.com:
See title, starting with a few FAQs

>how long and what do you do?
I started working on ships right out of university and ive made it my career, currently trying to get up to Cruise Director.

>where are you right now
Currently on a contract in the Caribbean, sailing out of Florida. About as entry-level as it gets.

>what’s the best cruise line for my vacation
If you have kids, Disney or Royal Caribbean. I can’t see reason to buy a cruise otherwise, it’s not a good travel method with the exception of a couple parts of the world (Alaska, Norway).

>can/do you sleep with the guests?
It’s prohibited and not worth it, there are plenty of female crew members who are down to fool around. I do have some adventurous friends though who partake. The bigger the ship the harder it is for them to catch you.

>I have no education/ambition, can I get a job on a ship?
Sure you can, but most likely you will work 8-10 hours a day every day for 6-8 months on a salary that cannot keep up with the western world’s cost of living,

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I worked on an expedition cruise ship visiting Antarctica, for 2.5 months.

I was expedition crew (I am also a qualified chief officer kek, but was on their using my Antarctic guiding experience). It was a pretty good gig.
-Cabin shared with one other member of exped crew (guy was a total bro)
-allowed to eat with guests, same food, very good quality
-long hours, hard work but did see aome really good places
-Upper class American guests, actually pretty OK to get on with

Visited 9-10 interesting sites (various wrecked ships, abandoned whaling stations etc.). Would recommend.

Now I work on a research vessel as chief officer. Have also worked on oil industry ships and container vessels, glad I got to experience a cruise ship.

If you are there for New Year’s Eve: go to high ground in central Reykjavík around 2200-2300. It’ll be dead as they’re all watching sone lame TV comedy thing. They’ll then come out for midnight and start launching a huge collection of fireworks. All Icelanders will do this. It is like a war zone.

Everyone except sone old dudes in very rural parts speaks English. Don’t worry about it.

You’ve heard of the Blue Lagoon. It’s crap. An expensive tourist trap. Go to the Sky Lagoon in Reykjavík itself. Every wee village has a geothernally heated pool you can go in for about £5.

How long are you going for, are you renting a car? Reykjavík is literally worth only a day trip but you see sone fabulous stuff driving around. Main roads will be passable outside of literal blizzards and even then you can pick your way through the roads with care.

I've been three times, staying 1-2 weeks each. You *must* get a scooter. I can't stress this enough. You will not experience Yakushima properly if you don't. The beautiful circuit around the island, and the wide, winding roads up into the mist covered mountains are made for riding.

If you can ride a bike, you can ride a scooter. An automatic 60cc is fine. Cars drive slowly & carefully. You'll rarely go over 50km/h, if at all. Most cars meander around at about 40km/h. There are hardly any corners so you'll get used to driving on the 'wrong' side of the road quickly. Just get one, believe me.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2362359
>Do any of you read while travelling?
I’m suspicious of anyone who doesn’t read while traveling. I very nearly always have at least one or two books on me for long flights. I also read ebooks on my phone, but that’s for when I finish my paper books.
>Got any good suggestions?
My taste is all over the place, a mix of artsy/high literature stuff and trash. Like others, I often like to read novels set in places in or near where I am going. I read Burgess’s Malayan Trilogy while in Southeast Asia (got a used paperback edition in a single volume; a lot of my books are secondhand paperbacks, and some of my favorite trashiest ones can be found in dollar bins at used bookstores), and also Orwell’s Burmese Days (although I think I bought that new at a bookstore in Thailand).

I believe I first discovered the work of the extremely prolific pulp novelist Edward S. Aarons being given away on a hotel bookshelf in Laos; he wrote dozens of spy thrillers set in exotic locales from the 1950s-1970s, and his descriptions of these settings are actually excellent, although the books are mostly at least a little stupid. Similar but much lower-quality (and first found by me on the same bookshelf) are the KILLMASTER series of novels written by a committee calling itself Nick Carter, the name of the protagonist, a sort of a low-budget, American James Bond type.

I also read most of Haruki Murakami’s novels on airplanes, back in the serious literature column. 1Q84 might be my favorite but they’re all interesting. His memoirs about running are, however, really boring.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361910

Totally legal, no one cares, US citizens can travel to Cuba under the "Support for the Cuba People" exemption. I'm a white American, went in May, zero issues in customs.

I stayed at a Casa. Basically a private apartment with a host family. They can be very helpful as even routine tasks (like getting internet for example) can be overly complicated.

For example take currency. Cuba used to have two currencies but now it's just one. The official bank exchange rate is 25-1 pesos to dollar, but on the street it's easily worth 100-1. People would buy up Euros & CAD the most, but also USD, Yen, Mexico Pesos. Cubans don't trust their currency so there's a large black market for it.

Since I had a host family they could convert the cash without worry of being ripped off in the street (lower rates, maybe even giving you old bills of Cubas defunct second currency).

In Havana, Old Town gets all the hype but Vedado is where you get away from the touts and tourists.

A big highlight was the Fábrica de arte Cubano, an old cigar factory turned into a multi level art space, entertainment venue, and club. Right on the edge before Miramar.

If you have time, Trinidad is another popular town to visit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I also went recently, specifically July. Also stayed in a Casa Particular in La Vibora. Departed from Miami, arrived in Havana via American Airlines. On the way out, said the script to the customs/border agent ie "I traveled to support the Cuba people. I stayed at a Casa Particular and I did not do commerce with any government or military entity.

>>2362317
Agree with everything in this post.

Also, taxis are pretty cheap, but like always, make sure you establish price ahead of time (and it helps to have your host clarify price too). Also, if you're in a high traffic area, you can wait a couple taxis and take a museum piece of a old Chevy or Ford, pretty awesome. But, I suggest walking if you can, especially through the more residential areas of the city, you'll get to see how locals live.

A couple other bullet points:
1. Both bottled water and toilet paper are sometimes hard to find (my host provided both, but not all do)
2. As far as I can tell there are 3 types of grocery stores:
- The first is a ratio store, and in general, only ratio books are accepted as "payment". You are not able to "purchase" items from these stores.
- The second is a general store that accepts pesos. These stores have pretty bad selection, and are a reflection of the command economy that Cuba largely has. I recall tomato sauce, vinegar, orange and lemon extract, and a type of wine basically dominating the entire store. Just vast quantities of like 5 items.
- The third store is also a general store, but it only appears to foreign currency (specifically dollars or euros). The selection at these stores are similar to what you'd find in a small grocery store in a western country. Hell, even western brands like Tide detergent and Axe body spray were available. Prices are high though. Clearly used to extract foreign currency.
3. There's not much wiggle room with police. If they ask you do to do something, just do it. Do not attempt to find a middle ground or convince them "it's ok".

I think the reason they slip so easily is because they have a lot of moving parts, have multiple holes, have poor QC, and are designed to be multifunctional. Basically a jack of all trades, but a master of none.

I think the only way to get reliable fitment is to get an adapter that is specifically made for a single setup. So if you're an American who is traveling to Europe, you might be better off getting an adapter that only accepts Type A plugs, and only plugs into Type C sockets. Something like pic related.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2361455
why not just buy a charger made for whichever country youre going to instead of fucking around with adapters

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361455
I only go really from the USA to Greece. Almost all of my devices are either usb-c, micro usb or apple lightning. All you need is one or two usb-a or usb-c adaptes to plug in to the wall socket of the country you are visiting. You can easily find those at the duty free shop of the airport you are departing or arriving at. Or at any electronic store after arrival. Just swap all the cables you already have accumulated in your home country into the new power plug for usb-a cables or usb-c cables.

For laptops, at least from the USA to Europe, you just need to unplug that end plug that fits into your American electric sockets. Leave it at home or in your suitcase. Then buy a European end adapter for a laptop power brick. My aunt who is native Korinthian told me some store where I could buy them for cheap when I came back in 2014 to Greece.

Unless you use something like an electric shaver that eschews the various usb charging standards you shouldn't need those huge adapter bricks. Unfortunately I had to buy one of those huge retarded things myself because I wanted to bring my Theragun mini percussion massager with me. I got a feeling if I planned ahead enough, I could have likely emailed Theragun and maybe have been able to buy a European power brick for it while still in the USA.

I post this in like every vegas thread, but here we go again. I visit like 4 times a year to visit my best friend who has lived in vegas for 20 years. Here is my guide.

For food, we almost always do asian food. West Spring Mountain BLVD has some of the best asian food in the US. Hachi, Ichiza, Ramen Sora, Tatsu, Viet Noodle House are all fucking insanely good. And it's off the strip, so the prices are actually really good.

For shit to do, go to Red Rock. Park at Calico Basin for free. Climb the rocks to the top. It'll be the best thing you do in vegas.

DONT stay at Circus Circus, NYNY, Excalibur, Oyo, the strat, the orleans, or pretty much any hotel on West Tropicana Ave.

We usually stay at Planet Hollywood. For some reason, they always have good deals. The rooms are nice and the mall downstairs has good food. The only downside is that parking is pretty far, at least a mile each way from the rooms to the parking garage.

Definitely go downtown at night and check out Fremont Street. It's fucking wild, especially on the weekends. There are always several free bands playing outside at night.

If you're into skateboarding, bring a board and go check out the free skateparks around town. There are like a dozen of them. Some are open all night.

Arizona Hotsprings is an awesome hike into a slot canyon to see some hot springs you can bath in. You can hike all the way to the colorado river. We saw big horn sheep last time we did it.

Don't go to the strip for hookers. Go to an asian massage parlor on Spring Mountain and get jerked off. $40 for the massage, $50 tip for the handjob. Don't exchange any bodily fluids with any working girls in vegas or you'll catch something.

For picking up drunk sluts, go downtown and hang at the casino bars.

Can we do a road-trip thread for lesser known towns and cities? I'm looking for some new ideas for an epic road-trip, US or Europe.

One of the best roadtrips Ive ever done was in Colorado. We did Durango to Ouray and then Telluride. All three towns are amazing in the winter. I didn't expect much from Durango, but the ski resort there is shockingly good. We ate at two really fucking great bars on the main street. We should have stayed another night in Ouray just for the hotsprings. One night wasn't enough. And Telluride is the best ski resort Ive ever been to in the US. The town is expensive, but worth every penny. It's also one of the most beautiful drives Ive ever done in my life through the mountains. Ive been dying to go back and explore the waterfalls and rivers in the summer.

If you do it in the winter, you need snow chains for damn sure.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361578
A solo road trip is a pretty depressing activity. You don't have friends who would go with you?

One of my favorite roadtrips is to drive up the 395 in California in the summer and take the back route into Yosemite National Park. You drive right at the base of the Sierra Mountain Range for most of the trip. You pass right by the tallest Mountain in the continental US, Mount Whitney. You go through a couple Indian reservations, past lakes, and a few ancient volcanic fields. The towns alog the way are really weird. Bishop has Erick Schat's bakery, probably the best bakery in the US. The 120 route into the back entrance of Yosemite is so beautiful that it's nearly indescribable. It's redwood forests, glaciers, pristine lakes, rivers, granite domes, waterfalls and meadows. It's my favorite drive in the US.

last_replies.com: Another epic rooadtrip is Salt Lake City Utah to Cody Wyoming. You take the route through Lava Hot Springs Idaho and then through Jackson Hole, then Yellowstone National Park and out the east entrance to Cody Wyoming. It's closed in the winter, so you have to do this one in the summer. And don't even attempt Yellowstone on a weekend. The crowds are insane. But God damn is it an epic drive. So much shit to see and do. You can stop in Lava Hot Springs and tube down a river that's fed from Hot Springs. It's like 80 degrees in the water all year. Lots of cool dive bars there too. White water rafting in Jackson, Yellowstone National Park, The Tetons, go to rodeo in Cody, eat roadside buffalo burgers, mountainbike in teton village, hit up park city utah, see the crazy mormon shit in temple square, etc etc. The whole drive is through epic mountains.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Hi /trv/

I'm going to travel the world and I don't have any money.

I've backpacking and hitchhiked the US and EU and been through some rough spots so I can handle myself while traveling. What's different now is I've learned I don't like cities and its people very much, and want to stick to forests, mountains, trails, and small towns. I think my new form of travel is PCT-esque; I'll follow mountain ranges and trails and skip into town to resupply while occasionally making stops at interesting cities or landmarks by hitching rides or local transport. What's different now is I don't plan on stopping either; this is the life I want and I want to keep going until I decide otherwise.

I have all the equipment I need and most of the know-how but I'm missing some key pieces, especially when traveling through foreign countries.
1) How do I find free (or REALLY cheap) accommodation while traveling? Camping in the woods is a non-issue for me. The occasional shower and warm bed is all I need to keep going. Finding accommodation has been a really big problem for me in large towns and cities because there aren't any camping spots and prices are expensive. This is the thing I'm most worried about.
2) Acquiring shelf-stable food. In my experience, walking into a restaurant and telling the waitress you're traveling the world and would like some free food often works. It doesn't work at a supermarket when all you need is two jars of peanut butter. How do I get food that'll keep me going for 2-3 days while hiking without money or working, ideally?
3) Safe havens when sick or injured. Occasionally I'll get sick or injured while traveling and just need a place to stay to recover. Where do I go?
4) Making money while traveling. I really don't care for money and if I have to work I want to work as little as possible. What kind of work should I be looking out for that a foreigner can do? Does busking work in foreign countries?

thanks yo

cont. in comments

last_replies.name: OP
last_replies.com:
>>2361892

additional reference: I've traveling before in foreign countries but that was traveling moreso traditionally. I was going city to city, had savings, and expected to stop when money ran out.

Now I want to hike mountains, forests, deserts in distant lands and I don't want to stop.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361892
Brah these questions are all very much country-specific. It would help to know your intended route. I'll try to answer some, as I lived this life a lot when I was younger.
>Where to stay for cheap in cities
Simple answer is don't go to cities. If I have to overnight in an urban sprawl I go to the busiest area, huddle up in a doorway, and get maybe 1 or 2 hours of sleep. Not ideal. Other times I've paid for transport to take me to the airport, and slept there.
>Free food
If you socialize with people, you tend to get fed. How exactly depends on what country. In poor countries, dudes will just take you home and feed you. In my experience in Europe, between snacks people would buy me, foraging wild food, and dumpster diving at gas stations, I ate pretty well. And I wasn't even comfortable asking for handouts like you seem to be. In Asia I've hardly ever been offered food, dunno why.
>Safe havens
People will help you out when you need help, if you're young and look like an innocent traveler. This is universal.

threads.com:
Thought some of you may be interested in this as the info online is scarce and conflicting. St Catherine is in the middle of South Sinai, on Egypt's Sinai Peninsula. Busses leave once daily from Cairo's Torgamon bus station at 9:30am. My ticket was 175 Egyptian, ~9USD. Bus took exactly 7 hours, few stops along the way, more than half empty but I bought my ticket the day in advance to be safe.

The two main things to do in the town are climbing Mt Sinai (picrel) and visiting the monastery. Climbing the mountain was incredible and one of the best experiences I've had over 40+ countries. Takes about 4 hours to the top if you're relatively fit, and I got up in time for the sunset which was magical. You have to (read: have to) take a Bedouin guide up the mountain. Mine was really nice and very liberal with time, bought snacks, and took all the photos I wanted. Guide costs 450 all in, which I was happy with because he was lovely.

Monastery is interesting enough and worthwhile for the icon gallery (museum) which has a cool collection of religious iconography and an old treaty signed by Muhammad promising to protect the monastery.

Blatant deception and assorted jewry from some of the local Bedouin population is a blemish on the trip, though. Camp/accommodation owners will essentially force you to take their ludicrously priced drivers from the camp to the monastery/mountain. 350 Egyptian for a 10 minute taxi, same on the way back. The owners of the place I stayed (450 Egyptian per night, Bedouin camp style place) had a massive shouting match with some woman who was staying there because she called them a mafia. Apparently she tried to take a local cab to the monastery and they found out and demanded she pay them as well as the local taxi, lmao. Standard tourist prices and disingenuous swindling behaviour apply throughout the town, expect things to be double the price of Cairo. The local population runs everything, and they take advantage of it to the fullest extent.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Both are reasonable countries to visit. I've probably spent a year total in Mexico over business trips and I've visited Thailand on leisure. I think it all depends on your food and entertainment preferences, I really prefer Mexican cuisine its diversity and flavor profile but I prefer Thailand when it comes to nightlife and partying.

I'm biased because of my job - both countries feel comparatively safe, I've genuinely never been robbed or threatened in either country and I find that the CNN mentality of many Americans concerning safety in both countries is pretty laughable. I've been hassled more in Miami and Chicago than I have walking around Mexico City, even though I am visibly white and not a local. Shootings aren't as often as people make it out to be and the only cities I've ever heard gun shots were Denver and Johannesburg.

Latin women tend to be hotter, imo, but aren't nearly as easy as Thais, especially when it comes to the Mexicanas with more European ancestry. Also I noticed that money doesn't impress nearly the same in Mexico City - in a few neighborhoods, like Polanco and Santa Fe, the girls came from families with more money than I'll ever see in my life. In Bangkok being a middle-aged European with more than a few thousand in your bank account will be far more impressive and the girls seem to care less if you're fat or ugly.

I wish I could say to split your time and make your decision that way - a few weeks in Mexico visiting museums and restaurants in Mexico City, going to some of the smaller cities in Mexico, etc. and then going to Thailand for the rest of your time might be a great way to compare experiences.

My job involves security, btw, and I've never known directly of a foreigner getting kidnapped, despite the millions of dumb drunk tourists who visit a year. It's mostly cartel activity in the north. In Thailand you don't have to worry about getting shot as much as stabbed by a drunk Thai wanting your pocket change or the deadly traffic.

I’m the guy above who has walked Camino. First of all, I can’t urge you strongly enough to go on a long-distance hike. It’s a truly life-changing experience — it sounds like your mind is already made up, but I just hope you know that it’s a genuinely good choice.

I have only read about Shikoku a little bit online (I’m considering doing it at some point way down the road, not this decade though). There are a number of websites dedicated to the trail and its community. I’m not sure how many of them are in English as I haven’t done a ton of research yet. Google is your friend here. Before the pandemic, over 100k people a year were walking the trail, so whatever you’re wondering, someone is certain to have asked and answered already.

For the most part, though, it’s a long walk like most other long walks. Do your reading, sure, but mainly just be mentally prepared for the task of walking 500 miles.

Buy good shoes, and even better socks. Take care of your feet and they’ll take care of you. Good luck out there.

Is that pic your setup?

I would highly recommend packing cubes, especially the compression type. The compression type have double zippers, if you use the second set of zippers you can compress the clothes inside a bit to maximize space. I used to use those vacuum sealed clothing bags, but they were messier, even the vacuum bag gets air in it and starts decompressing -- plus it sucked sucking the air out at hotels without recourse to a vacuum. Now I stick with compression packing cubes. I personally have the Eagle Creek Pack It compression packing cubes and some cheaper ones that I got at TJ Maxx(US retail store).

I also use various other organizer containers for cables to charge my electronics, my electronics, for my bicycling accessories, I use some hanging toiletry organizer for my toothbrush, floss, toothpaste, etc.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I'm planning to go somewhere in late January with some of my lads. It'll be an extended weekend trip of about three nights.

In my infinite autism I have compiled a spreadsheet detailing the various destinations I've looked at. I'll explain the columns and then I'd like your opinion on what destination you think we should pick!

>TRANSPORTATION COST
This column details the estimated transportation cost per person for the trip. It includes: gas for driving to the airport, airport parking and a two-way flight ticket. The price is in euros.

>HOSTEL COST
The estimated hostel cost per night per person. I've only done some rudimentary checks on booking.com to get a feel for how much decent accommodation should cost at each destination. This then factors in to the predicted cost of the entire trip (3 nights * estimated hostel price). The price is in euros.

>RESTARURANT PRICES
I used numbeo.com to compare the average price of a cheap restaurant in each location with the price in Skopje, North Macedonia. The reason I chose Skopje is that I know how ridiculously cheap it is and that it was the first international trip I planned myself, so I use it as a benchmark. I then use the relative prices to predict the cost of the entire trip (2 meals * €5 * price factor).

>GROCERY STORE PRICES
I once again used numbeo.com to compare the prices and I chose Skopje for the aforementioned reasons. The grocery price factor then factors in to the total trip cost like this: (€2.5 * price factor). When we do our incredibly ghetto budget travelling we usually don't eat out for breakfast, so the €2.5 includes breakfast and any snacks we want to buy.

cont.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I'm starting to plan out a 2023 Costa Rica vacation but I'm struggling. What are the must-see/do things in Costa Rica?
I know that I want to do some zip-lining, hot springs/volcanos, and go to the beach.
Should I rent a car or rely on taxis and should I book one hotel or several to see more of the country?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Must sees/do:

-La Fortuna/Arenal, for volcano, zip lining, hot springs, etc.
-Manuel Antonio Beach and Park.
-Tamarindo (aka, Tamagringo) for larger beach town on pacific side.
-Puerto Viejo for smaller beach town on Caribbean side. Water here will be more clear and blue.

Car rental is best option for getting around to multiple locations. Be aware that locals here walk directly on the very edge of the road. You have to be alert always, I’m sure several get ran over every month.

Many call Costa Rica a tourist trap in general. But just be aware that it’s not cheap there. If you are looking for cool nature/animals, beaches, it’s a great place to visit. Locals are generally really friendly and eager to make new friends.

>I'll counter with MY anecdotal experience in which Schengen countries DO ask awkward questions, and a lot of them. I've almost been denied entry multiple times because they suspected me of coming to work illegally.
This surprises me a great deal, so I have lots of questions:

Which Schengen countries were you entering on these multiple occasions, from where, and on what passport?

Were you on one-way tickets that made it look as though you weren’t planning to leave, or something? Were you coming back for your third 90 day period in a year?

And what does “almost denied entry” look like? Just being asked questions about your itinerary, or did they actually accuse you of working illegally, or tell you they didn’t want to let you in? What made you think you were close to getting refused entry?

Anyway, as an American who traveled to Europe many times before moving here, my experience has always been much more like >>2360393 suggests. I don’t know that I’ve ever been asked any questions at all, over the course of probably a dozen inbound trips. I might have indicated that I was on holiday, and as needed I could have shown return tickets leaving in less than 90 days, but I don’t think I’ve ever been asked to.

>>2360348
To OP, staying within the 90-days-in-180 limits is quite important, not least because after the 90 day mark you are typically required to be a local tax resident. But it’s possible to decamp for a non-Schengen country or series of countries in Europe to reset the clock if you don’t want to go all the way back to the States. You can enter the UK for up to six months visa-free, or Albania for a whole year, or either Romania or Croatia for 90 days each.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Its a legit ticket. The app takes advantage of various airline refund schemes. For example for all outbound US flights they are all required to give you 24 hours for a full refund. In other words you can do what onwardticket does on your own if you tried

completely depends on where you are going, and what passport you have

last_replies.com:

The question is not if they check but if they have the means to verify.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2360562
Another hunanon living in Eastern Hungary, guess I’ll answer. You can try Eger, a historical city with a huge fortress and other sites, many wineries with some good red wine. A bit more to the east, Tokaj is the center of our most famous wine region, there are vineyards with accomodation and good food.
In the middle of the Great Plain you have Hajdúszoboszló, a bath town cramped with wellness hotels. It’s really only good for some sleazy weekends where you don’t want to do anything else but bathing, massages and shitton of good buffet food. Rich Russians love it there.
There’s also Debrecen, the second largest city, but I don’t really know what I’d do there as a tourist and I’ve lived there half my life lmao. It’s got awesome cafés and restaurants, a few festivals and some historical sites.
Hungarian countryside has some real gems scattered around. It’s the best if you get to know some Hungarians who can help you travel around because you can easily spend a week doing a roundtrip visiting some cool landscapes and eating top tier cuisine for pocket change, compared to other European countries.
